stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the final level, Course 15, implementing a 'Mario Paint' retro section. The stream focused on creating the painting and scoring mechanics, discussing the technical challenges on N64, and modeling the 3D NPC that will judge the player's artwork.

development_findings.summary: Work is focused on Course 15, the final course, which features a 'Mario Paint' retro section where players must draw Mario to earn a star.
Kaze revealed a deep technical aspect of the N64 hardware: an accessible 'ninth bit' for every byte, totaling about 1MB of 'hidden memory' that can be used with specific tricks.
development_findings.quote: The Nintendo 64 has around one megabyte of hidden memory that you don't really use. But there's ways to use it... secretly, all the bytes on the N64 are nine bits.

development_findings.summary: Kaze decided against using the 'Undo Dog' from Mario Paint as the judging NPC to avoid creating a false expectation of an undo feature. He instead chose the robot from Mario Paint/Maker.
development_findings.quote: I'm a little bit scared that the Undo Dog will make people think that they can undo. And I will absolutely not add undo to this.

development_findings.summary: The painting mechanic will not have an 'undo' function to punish mistakes, but will include a 'reset' button to start over completely.
development_findings.quote: You fuck up, you lose your points. That's what it's going to be. You don't get undo, but you get reset. That should be good enough for you guys.

development_findings.summary: Kaze created a custom, non-recursive flood fill algorithm for the paint bucket tool to avoid overflowing the N64's limited stack memory.
He switched the texture filtering for the Mario drawing canvas from the default to point-filtered, resulting in a much crisper, pixel-art look that he preferred.
development_findings.quote: Oh, yeah, that looks way more crisp. I don't know why I didn't try it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze modeled the judging NPC, the Mario Paint robot, in 3D from scratch, using a 2D sprite from the original game as a reference and taking some creative liberties to adapt it.

Kaze dismissed a viewer's concern about T-junctions in his 3D model, explaining that they are not an issue on N64 when polygons are world-axis aligned due to fixed-point math preventing rounding errors.
development_findings.quote: If you do stuff like this and it's not world aligned, then yes. It can open worlds. But you know, it will be perfectly aligned.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering turning the project into an original indie game after release by swapping out all Nintendo assets, but acknowledges he would need to consult a lawyer about the legality.
context_findings.quote: I'm planning to make indie games eventually, there is this idea of maybe asset swapping Return to Yoshi's Island when it's done and releasing it under my own IP.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the current political and internet climate is too sensitive to create a political parody ROM hack, unlike when he made one in 2016.
context_findings.quote: When I made Trump 64 in 2016, you could do anything on the internet... But if I do the same thing in 2024 with the Trump 64 ROM hack, people will murder me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed a creative philosophy of needing to move on to new ideas rather than repeating past successes.
context_findings.quote: You cannot redo a hundred times what you've done in the past. It's not because it works that... I have to move on.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's personal game preference leans towards open-world exploration and the 'journey between dungeons', and he generally dislikes boss fights and 2D platformers (with Yoshi's Island being an exception).
context_findings.quote: What I like in Zelda games is all the open world and exploration and not really the dungeons.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a sponsorship deal with Roblox and is planning a paid stream where his community can join him in-game.
Kaze expressed frustration with the broader ROM hacking community, specifically mentioning feeling 'gaslit' by a user named Falco and the 'Romnigan community'.
context_findings.quote: The entire Romnigan community is trying to gaslight me.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentions that he and his wife, Zeina, are playing through The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess together in their personal time.
zeina.quote: Me and Zeina, we're currently playing through Twilight Princess.

key_stories.title: Choosing the Art Critic NPC
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed a character to judge the player's painting. He rejected the 'Undo Dog' to avoid promising an undo feature he wouldn't implement, and instead chose the Mario Paint robot, which he then began creating as a 3D model for the level.
key_stories.challenge: The game needed an NPC to judge the player's artwork in the Mario Paint level, but the most obvious choice presented a design problem.
key_stories.process: Kaze first considered the 'Undo Dog' from Mario Paint but rejected it because he didn't want to implement an undo feature and felt the character would create that expectation. He then researched other Mario Paint characters, settled on the save/load robot, found a clean GIF of its sprite, and started modeling it in Blender.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze chose the robot from Mario Paint/Maker as a suitable alternative and began the process of ripping its sprite and modeling it in 3D for the game.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm a little bit scared that the Undo Dog will make people think that they can undo. And I will absolutely not add undo to this.

key_stories.title: The Indie Game Pivot Strategy
key_stories.summary: Kaze revealed a potential long-term plan to convert 'Return to Yoshi's Island' into a commercial indie game. By swapping out Mario and all other Nintendo-related assets, he could release it as his own original IP, though he noted the legal questions involved.
key_stories.challenge: How to leverage the massive amount of work put into a ROM hack for a future career in independent game development.
key_stories.process: While discussing his future plans, Kaze floated the idea of creating an original IP by replacing all the game's assets, including Mario, after the hack is complete. This would allow him to sell the game commercially.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze is seriously considering this path but acknowledges the legal hurdles, indicating a long-term strategy beyond the ROM hacking scene.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm planning to make indie games eventually, there is this idea of maybe asset swapping Return to Yoshi's Island when it's done and releasing it under my own IP, because the only vanilla actor I use in this game is Mario himself.

key_stories.title: Hacking the N64 for Mario Paint
key_stories.summary: Kaze explained the deep technical solutions required to make the Mario Paint feature work on the N64. He detailed his knowledge of a 'hidden megabyte' of memory on the console and described how he built a custom, non-recursive algorithm to handle the paint bucket tool without crashing.
key_stories.challenge: Implementing a memory-intensive painting feature on the N64, a console with severe memory limitations.
key_stories.process: While developing the painting mechanic, Kaze explained two technical solutions. First, he detailed the existence of a 'ninth bit' in N64 memory that can be accessed for extra storage. Second, he explained that a standard recursive flood-fill would crash the game, so he built his own solution using a temporary memory allocation as a stack.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze demonstrated his deep technical knowledge of the N64, explaining how this 'hidden memory' works and how he created a custom flood-fill algorithm to avoid overflowing the console's stack.
key_stories.key_quote: The Nintendo 64 has around one megabyte of hidden memory that you don't really use. But there's ways to use it.
